This section describes how to connect the ownCloud Android App to your ownCloud. Connecting

Physical Location of User Files
Compared to earlier versions of this app (< 2.19), the location for files created or managed by this app is called
Scoped Storage
. Scoped Storage is, in contrast to Shared Storage, protected and part of the app. It is saved in the device’s storage (persistent memory) and limited by its capacity. Internal tests have successfully passed using more than 50GB of Scoped Storage without any issues.
""

Files are now safe and private and can only be accessed by other apps that use the
Documents Provider
. Document provider — A content provider that allows a storage service to reveal the files it manages
""
When a connection is removed or the app is uninstalled, all files are removed for that connection or the whole app by design - securing data privacy. Consider if there is  there’s enough
internal storage capacity
for your files to be synced by the app. At this point, you’ll be on the
"All Files"
screen, which you see below.

As a rule of thumb, check the capacity necessary via the ownCloud web access first before enabling a sync for a particular mount and or path using offline access for files. For best security, your ownCloud server should be
SSL-enabled
so that you can connect via HTTPS. The ownCloud Android App will test your connection as soon as you provide it and tell you if you entered it correctly. If your server has
a self-signed SSL certificate
, you’ll get a warning that it is not to be trusted. The options are:
Manage Users Accounts
Current Uploads

Application Settings
To use Two-Factor Authentication, ownCloud server must have the
the OAuth2 app
installed, configured, and enabled. Please contact your ownCloud administrator for more details.

Enter your server URL, login name, password, and click the
Connect
button. Click the
eyeball
to the right of your password to expose your password. If this happens, click the
YES
button to accept the certificate and complete your account setup.
